comments.commentBody: Please learn what a Ponzi scheme is. Wikipedia will help you.

Bitcoin is obviously a Ponzi scheme... It could still become one of the most famous in history.

For millennia, governments struck coinage. Now they have farmed out the function to private money creators called bankers. Interestingly, for nearly 2,000 years in the West, the government created money (with a face value higher than its real value), but taxes were farmed out to private enterprises. Now it's the other way around. Why? Because the plutocrats have found money creation to be their best trick in a long time, to get ever more power.

The decades of prosperity after World War Two came after nearly two decades of massive equalitarian intervention of governments in the economy, characterized by massive technological and sociological development. That's what's needed now.
http://patriceayme.wordpress.com/2013/12/22/zero-point-energy-machine/

There is a difference between money and wealth. In a starving society a food warehouse may be great wealth and a wagon full of paper money may only serve to build a fire. Today personal wealth may be piles of cash and stocks and bonds which could disappear with hyper-inflation to which is now including gold and other precious metals, artwork, jewelry, land, mines, oil and gas wells, large buildings, factories, mansions, fresh water supplies, which always are in demand, of great value are game pieces in the game of remaining very rich even if the financial system collapses and there is civil disorder.

There are some superrich families and individuals in America and the world and they want to convert a lot o their currency into hard wealth that will insulate them from the financial system and they will become as in the 17th century, the kings, princes and lords of there future.

They have transferred great wealth from the masses by stealing their labor by using it and not delivering a living wage. They have bought a political party and some greedy politicians who enact laws as they demand as the great majority becomes pauperized and then blamed for being lazy. This will continue until we elect a government that values people over property and taxes not only income but wealth beyond what is healthy in a democracy. Pretty soon they will demand that we salute them and bow. The tax law made them and can be used to reduce this inequality which is killing us as intended.

"The mine has a terrible reputation for both human rights abuses (rapes, beatings and killings by security personnel) and environmental damage (vast quantities of potentially toxic tailings dumped into a nearby river)."

When we let such things into our economy, we are making it part of ourselves. We are leveling down. We are doing it, as we take the benefit, and as we put ourselves into competition with it.

This is where we must look for major corrective to world trade. It is not necessary to do this. Sweden doesn't. They're doing just fine without doing this.

We make it illegal to pay bribes, even in countries where others pay bribes, where that is the method of government. We just won't do it.

We can apply the same thing to abuses of workers and environment that are made part of our economy.

It is wrong to be party to this. It harms us to be party to this. It damages our own economy, our own people, even as we pay the way for this to be done to others.

We already don't participate in similar things. We can draw a line. We do draw lines. We need to draw a line on this.

I agree with all the other comments: so refreshing to read about a couple not bound by conventional ways of being "a couple," not defeated by their many arguments, and able to survive the many families tragedies with energy and determination.

I wish them much luck in their years together.

Bitcoin is modeled on gold; read Nick Szabo's blog entry on "Bit Gold," a predecessor and inspiration for Bitcoin. Bitcoins are not unique numbers analogous to prime numbers. Bitcoins are just ordinary numbers, ranging from zero to a maximum of 21 million, "locked" in metaphorical "safes" (bitcoin addresses, which are virtually infinite in number). Each bitcoin "safe" is secured by powerful cryptography so that bitcoin sent to that address can only be transferred out of the address by the owner of the address. The Bitcoin network ensures that bitcoin cannot be moved by anyone except the possessor of the "key" to the "safe" in which those bitcoin are locked. The Bitcoin network also ensures that the owner of bitcoin cannot "double-spend" the bitcoin. Once bitcoin has been transferred from one address to another, the owner of the first address cannot re-spend those bitcoin. They now belong to whoever controls the destination address.

Although it is obvious that once you hand over a gold bar to someone you no longer have it to hand to someone else, this property of physical gold is not trivial to engineer for an electronic entity.

Bitcoin is the first time a decentralized electronic commodity that is easily transferrable is mathematically guaranteed to be scarce.

The government isn't a business and doesn't need to make a profit. It prints its own money. Where the government spends money, people can prosper, if it is wisely spent.
We can spend the money we earn by giving it to the speculators to gamble with, to the military to blow things up, to other countries to re build what we blew up, to the already wealthy in the form of entitlements like carried interest and stipends for not growing crops. Or we can spend it on rebuilding our roads, bridges and schools, cutting pollution and poison in our food and water supplies. We can spend to improve our lives, or spend it to cater to a select few. Either way, the money gets spent.
I prefer quality of life over paying some CEO 300 times what he pays his secretary. I prefer having the bridges inspected and fixed over allowing some hedge fund speculator to game the system at our expense.

With all due respect, no one has been more on target about the economy (i.e., how monetary and fiscal decisions and inaction effect the economy) over last 6 or 7 years than professor Krugman.

And just remember that supply follows demand, and without a strong middle class, the demand that fuels our economy will not be strong enough. There are plenty of real jobs and real bridges that can be funded through thoughtful fiscal policy.

Rid the supreme court of the corporate lackeys, and restore the equal importance of all citizens in the democratic process, and you will see the power of the US middle class restored. And the strength of the US economy soar.
The government will go bankrupt, run out of money the day after the NFL runs out pf points.

Spending money on a bridge to nowhere, or a road no one needs, or subsidizing a company like Solyndra, all seem to be very similar to mining gold or making bitcoins. Unwanted bridge, road, or solar panel factory will sit idle just like gold, as Dr. Krugman correctly points out.

No private company can stay in business by spending for the sake of spending. Even governments will go bankrupt if they try. If that is indeed what Keynes advocated, he was dead wrong, so is Dr. Krugman.

So much speculation with unearned billions, so little real accomplishment that improves peoples lives. Those with money now leverage their advantage to destroy jobs instead of create them. In the Chicago area the Wall Street hedge fund Jana Partners is bringing down the areas second largest grocery chain, Dominick's, (owned by Safeway), that could cost area employees 6,000 jobs. This would be called a drive by shooting in some places, since the hedge fund job killers exited much of their investment as soon as they drove the price of Safeway up enough to make their quick millions. Millions that weren't earned but stolen, by killing the livlihood of people they didn't know or care about, just to make a quick buck.

I think Keynes solutions are better than the Captains of Wall Street, but to get there we can't just pay people to dig holes and then pay them to fill them in again. We need to expand the money supply to offset the hoarding that accomplishes nothing, and then we need to make something good happen with the expenditures so people who are easily swayed by the constant barrage of trickle down drivel can actually see things tangible develop, like an improved transportation system, a renewed space program, and a working and affordable healthcare system (hopefully soon), that wiill make them realize it's worth it.

The sad reality is that money was, and remains the means to perpetuate the inequality that has become the hallmark of our dysfunctional society. It is a means that gives form to a pyramid of injustice, leaving must of us crushed at the bottom of a huge pyramid.
Instead of setting us free money, as it was intended, it has enslaved almost all of us.

David,

We know from history that Stalinism is a pox on humanity.

Democratic socialism has been slain in its crib by communists and capitalists alike every time the faintest whisper of it has been heard.
They have gone to "better" schools, yes. More intelligent? Not necessarily. The average street urchin has a lot more on the ball; their lives depend on it.

The Russians have a joke that goes: "Everything Marx said about Capitalism is the truth, unfortunately, everything he said about Communism was a lie.'

Marx won't ever quite die, because his problem definition was so profound and so accurate.

The reason Marx seems like he should die, is because his solution definition was so profoundly flawed.

The primary problem as I see it, is the very wealthy do not have to put their money back into the economy to stay rich. The idea behind a high inheritance tax, was to keep a few families from taking control of the government as they had in France and England but being rich, they have been able to change that. We should correct this.

Just because you were born rich, should not exclude you from having to contribute to the economy. What those who have elevated themselves above 90% of the population are doing, is risking losing all to populist anger, and a public that can no longer afford the products that bring them so much wealth.

Most rich are better educated, and are more intelligent than we like to give them credit for. J.D Rockefeller was one of the most despised men in America, but he was very smart, he saw opportunity, where others did not. Sam Walton capitalized on the public's want for low cost goods,no matter the quality, his heirs have very smart people managing their money.

We know from history, Marxist Socialism does not work,. No matter what is done, there will always be a core of the disadvantaged. We need to see that their children can get good educations, and stay healthy so as not to be and expense to the public. They all need some way to earn a living, but who will provide that, and how? That excludes those who can not for some reason, like age, ill health, physical limitations. And we need a retirement system so they do not end up on the street.

Any currency with a fixed (even if not yet reached) limit on the number of coins is doomed to become a speculators heaven then nightmare. Bit coins, gold, a dollar bill all have little (gold has some) or no intrinsic value, and in any event are only worth what someone is willing to pay.

A gold standard would be a catastrophe for the world economy. Have fun with the bit coins or buy illegal substances. Just get out before the bubble bursts.

Until the right-wing-nuts destroy the full faith and credit of the US, our proven governmental stability and strong economy will keep dollars as the world's reserve currency.

The point is that all currency is nothing but thin air, backed by its utility in necessary transactions, which is based on little more than peoples' faith.

As soon as Bitcoin could be bought with another currency, it became as vulnerable as any other currency to speculation and control by the plutocrats.

We have a famous saying in India. "First they ignore you, then make fun of you, then criticize you and then they accept you". So, Prof is making fun of Bitcoin after saying that it is bit of thin air in his previous article. I am still surprised that Prof Krugman still compares Bitcoin with Tulip mania!
The concept on which Bitcoin is based on is still strong. It defines the probability of which a legitimate transaction can be made without using an intermediary. So, the mining activity is only creating transactions without duplicating a transaction.
So, what is the best choice? Governments should regulate the printing of currencies and enable transactions using similar theory to reduce overheads in transactions.
Considering that credit card transactions, bank transactions and for that matter our taxes to Government for the services they render are only stored as line items, I don't think that Bitcoin entries are thin air.

Kruguman is for a Keynesian jobs program. He has been calling for one since 2008. In the absence of one, fiscal policy is the only tool left.

Besides, what would you have the fed do? As you state, we are in a depressed economy (with the continued risk of deflation). Should we raise interest rates now to fend off future hypothetical hyperinflation? I don't know if it would work, but I do now that higher interest rates now would kill demand and push the economy into further recession or depression.

If inflation starts to pick up, then tighten the monetary policy, but there is no reason to in the current context of weak growth and weak inflation.
Fly high indeed!
With the money one saves on low cost fares and no-frills transport, one can buy enough of the sedative of one's choice to block out the entire,  miserable experience.

With Warren taking herself out of the running, I fear there won't anyone who will give Hillary a run for her money if only to get her to make campaign promises she'll have to keep. I don't see Hillary as the one who would push for the tremendous effort it will take to get money out of politics.

It all comes down to ideologically empowered ignorance, greed, and power.

So much of what's wrong in this world, including the destructive mining in Papua New Guinea and elsewhere, and the e-coining frenzy that just accelerates, all point to the desire of certain groups of people to follow ideas that may have very deleterious consequences based on ideology; a lust for more and more, despite the finitenes of our material world (death and the afterlife are infinite, our lives and our world are not); and the power that accrues with various forms of money, power to exceed laws, power to make them in one's own favor and image, power to play God.

Of course many of these folks could do this with a pencil and piece of paper, or even in their imaginations alone, but that is not good enough.

The result, perhaps saddening, perhaps maddening, perhaps provocative enough for a majority of us to wake up, is that because of this undying failed ideology, greed and will and lust to power, we all ultimately will suffer in the end.

The government isn't a business and doesn't need to make a profit. It prints its own money. Where the government spends money, people can prosper, if it is wisely spent.
We can spend the money we earn by giving it to the speculators to gamble with, to the military to blow things up, to other countries to re build what we blew up, to the already wealthy in the form of entitlements like carried interest and stipends for not growing crops. Or we can spend it on rebuilding our roads, bridges and schools, cutting pollution and poison in our food and water supplies. We can spend to improve our lives, or spend it to cater to a select few. Either way, the money gets spent.
I prefer quality of life over paying some CEO 300 times what he pays his secretary. I prefer having the bridges inspected and fixed over allowing some hedge fund speculator to game the system at our expense.

Please.  Obama's point was that individuals don't build businesses all by themselves, without a social, legal, and physical infrastructure that all of us rely upon.  I have been an entrepreneur for most of my working life.  I rely upon patents, copyrights and trademarks to protect my companies' intellectual property.  I rely on employees who learned many of their skills at public schools.  My companies' utilize the Internet, the result of federally-funded R&D.  I could go on, but the point is obvious.  Even if you run a hot dog stand I suspect you sell hot dogs inspected by the USDA (at least occasionally).
Lots of chronyship in for profit prisons.  Ever wonder why we have the highest percentage of incarceration rates in the world.

Professor,

You may want to start next time by looking at Glenn Hubbard, Dean of Columbia's Business School and all the shenanigans that he has been part of it.

It is not only the bankers, it is also the academics in Ivy League universities, highly corrupt corporate types in the following industries: tobacco, oil, chemicals, pharma, for profit education etc.

Tobacco executives lie in front of Congress that they knew 'nothing,' about nicotine.

For profit education - one industry that is even worse than sub prime mortgage. These guys recruit poor kids, load them up with Deptt of Education that they will never be able to repay, and then provide them no education or skills to get a job.

Only one thing is missing: Lord Romney and Lady Romney. Please cheer for our horses!

The rules are encoded into the software used by bitcoin miners, exchanges, and users to decide which proposed transactions can be written into the ledger.  These rules cannot be easily changed without disrupting transaction processing.  Necessary changes are coordinated by the Bitcoin Foundation and the software developers.  Newly created bitcoins are paid to miners who operate the network and maintain the ledger.   Businesses that accept bitcoins either sell them immediately or hold them for speculation.  Non-speculators would buy bitcoins as needed to transact online or international business, but a stable market value is needed.  I don't see how that will happen under the current rules.

EJ Huff, Your response begs the question.  The identity of the code writers and those who direct the Bitcoin Foundation (if there is one-- the Foundation is not readily apparent on the Bitcoin website) is not made clear on the Bitcoin Internet site.  In the absence of clarity, I am skeptical.

The identify of Satoshi Nakamoto, the original inventor of BitCoin, is unknown. However all of the source code running the network is opensource so it can be vetted by the entire community.

I suppose if you couldn't read or understand the code and math behind it, you would be taking a risk to get involved in BitCoin. But if you are okay with trusting all of the other smart mathematicians and computer scientists who have taken a look and gotten involved, you can trust BitCoin. If there was a large glaring error in the math, it would have come out by now.

Re bitcoins: who is creating the rules concerning the issuance of this digital currency, and why?  Commerce is already digital, although we of course typically trade in national currencies.  Bitcoins are potentially interesting and subversive in that they suggest the potential for consumers to create new mediums of digital exchange (yes, the desirability of new exchange mediums should be evaluated and vetted), but I can't understand why they would be accepted without a clear understanding of who controls their issuance and to what end.
A 15% federal tax rate on carried interest is not "confiscation" of assets, and it wouldn't be if it were increased to 20%.  Fair sharing of costs of government is not confiscation.

What do you mean? The first two years of his presidency were spent putting out the great fire known as the financial meltdown that required a heavy jolt in the form of bailouts. There really wasn't time or money to rebuild america when the country teetered close to full economic collapse.
What's more, massive unemployment didnt really hit till the toxic mortgage crisis spread to main street and companies downsized. This process took 2 years at which point the tea party was born.

Unless you have lived in a bubble since then, nothing the president proposes ever gets passed. By design, naturally. So stop talking about infrastructure spending which won't pass congress until democrats take the house and retain control of the senate.
They may have, Howie. And they certainly outplayed the Seahawks today.

Any currency with a fixed (even if not yet reached) limit on the number of coins is doomed to become a speculators heaven then nightmare. Bit coins, gold, a dollar bill all have little (gold has some) or no intrinsic value, and in any event are only worth what someone is willing to pay.

A gold standard would be a catastrophe for the world economy. Have fun with the bit coins or buy illegal substances. Just get out before the bubble bursts.

Until the right-wing-nuts destroy the full faith and credit of the US, our proven governmental stability and strong economy will keep dollars as the world's reserve currency.

Expanding on the discussion of money and the Fed, the Fed has a dual mandate to limit both inflation and unemployment. But it’s really a single mandate: to balance the forces of inflation and deflation by finding an optimum money supply.

Recently the Fed has pushed dollars into the economy by buying bonds. (Except that the banks are sitting on the money rather than circulating it.) If inflation becomes too high, the Fed can suck those dollars back out of the economy by selling bonds.

The Fed can’t do everything. We need political leaders who competently apply Keynesian fiscal and monetary policies.

During an economic slowdown, there is a way for the Fed to help boost jobs and growth that costs the tax payers little or nothing, doesn’t permanently increase the money supply, and doesn’t add to net federal debt.

Instead of US gov’t borrowing: The Fed can create dollars and lend them to Treasury at a miniscule interest rate such as ½%. Set up an agency to disburse the funds. This agency can lend the funds for mortgages or businesses, which will pay the loans off. As part of stimulus, the loans can bear a low rate of interest such as 1%. When paid back, the dollars can be returned to the Fed which will shred them. The agency can also lend for to renewable energy projects. The revenues will amortize the loans. The agency could lend to state and local gov’t for infrastructure projects. Fees and taxes could amortize infrastructure loans over a long period (thus a low user tax).

Regarding inflation fears, there are two other options in addition to the Fed selling bonds.

Volcker showed that inflation can be tamed by raising interest rates.

Inflation can also be tamed by increasing taxes.

These three options show that inflation does not need to be a problem. Past times of hyperinflation were due to incompetent government leadership.
No Harry, past periods of hyperinflation were due to shortages, not enough stuff.

On the gold standard, most of the money wasn't the metal. People put their gold into banks, and banks had to lend that gold out. (I suggest reading Making Money, by Terry Pratchett.) Conservative banks kept 20% of the gold in reserve. If the gold was loaned on good loans, and if depositors having more than 20% of the deposits demanded their gold back, the bank sold the loans for gold. This meant that 80% of the money consisted of loans and deposits backed by gold, not physical gold.

In a panic, everyone was sure those loans are worthless, so the bank couldn't sell them, and only the first 20% of depositors who rushed to withdraw got their gold back. The other 80% lost everything.

The Federal Reserve was formed to buy good loans for gold and prevent panics. But in '29, banks loaned money to buy into a stock bubble, creating a leveraged bubble, and when stocks crashed, those loans were worthless. The Federal Reserve was only authorised to buy good loans, not worthless ones. So deposits, all of which were, in theory, backed by gold, disappeared. Permanently.

Paper money gives governments more flexibility. From ancient times until the European Enlightenment, China had the world's largest economy and a stable paper currency. The Chinese economy needed the flexibility of fiat money to grow. (After 1940, a corrupt, incompetent government allowed hyperinflation, and the Communists took over.)

"As I see it, Assad will continue to killing any one that does not accept his rule, same as his father did."

When Hafez Assad attacked Hama in 1982 he was suppressing a major uprising by the Muslim Brotherhood. The death toll was high but quite a few people (even Sunni) considered it justified as the continuation of the Brotherhood uprising would have resulted in a civil war. Remember that at this time Lebanon's civil war was raging.

The main factor determining whether the war will go on is the Gulf States and specially Saudi Arabia. As long as they as investing massive amounts of money in the uprising it will not end. The big question for Geneva will be whether the US has any influence in Riad.

Agree. As one talking head put it: The outcome will be one side will win and the other will suffer.

Merry Christmas and Happy Holidays.

As I see it, Assad will continue to killing any one that does not accept his rule, same as his father did.

However, it looks as if he will be deposed eventually and when that happens, the country will be thrown into chaos, most likely to be taken over by the military officer that can assemble the largest following. Some parts of the country will have to be ceded to sectarian groups such as the Kurds.

No one country will be able to bring peace to the region for a long time. Only the other Islamic countries can bring any resolve, and as long as the various factions retain their animosity to each other. A coalition needs to formed to contain the conflict within the country. Even if the west friendly rebels do take control of the central government, they will not be able to keep the whole country together.

It will not matter if Assad stays or goes, the war within will continue.
